Appearance: Seemingly opaque brown, but actually a dark, murky shade of ruby red. Some carbonation visible. Pours to an average-sized, tan, foamy head which retains and laces well enough.

Smell: Discernible brown ale maltiness with milk chocolate and iced coffee.

Taste: We tend to associate coffee beers with stouts, but why not brown ales? After all, their inherent sweetness helps to pair with the natural confectionery flavors often found in coffee brews. Cigar City Cubano-Style Espresso Brown Ale is a great example of what I mean. 

This beer is essentially a liquid candy bar - complete with flavors of milk chocolate, vanilla, caramel and of course coffee. You don¬ít tend to taste coffee in candy bars all that much, but here it¬ís used as a flavoring complement, rather than raw bitterness and astringency you tend to find in coffee stouts. It¬ís not that it works better here, just differently. It¬ís indeed quite sweet, but the bitterness from the hops and the espresso beans prevent it from becoming cloying. Well-balanced for sure, but still sweet enough to work as a dessert or to pair with a cheese tasting.

Drinkability: What really impressed me about Cigar City Cubano-Style Espresso Brown Ale wasn¬ít just how much I enjoyed the palette, but how easy it was to drink. As much as I love imperial stouts that offer a similar flavor profile, they can be quite taxing. This brew has the lighter body, calmer, more comfortable mouthfeel and smoother finish I prefer in a standard beer. There¬ís a lot of flavor for only 5.5% ABV, though it¬ís so light on my system I¬ím quite tempted to open another bottle immediately.

Bottle gifted by Chaney. Prost!

The beer is brown and somewhat hazy, with a thin, beige collar that leaves a fair amount of lacing behind. The aroma consists of coffee beans, tobacco, smoke, roast, leather, and some mustiness. Jeff nailed it - "This beer smells like John Wayne." The flavor is more coffee forward than the nose would indicate, with less intricacies than were presented to the olfactory senses. The base beer is still distinguishable, and not overrun by the often dominating coffee scents. The feel is somewhat thin, with moderate carbonation. A decent brew, and quite interesting. Not my favorite coffee brew, but intriguing and worth a try.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-02-2011

12 oz bottle served in a Deschute tulip. Big thanks eorwar for the share.

A: Pours a semi clear brown with a thin light tan head forming on the pour. It recedes to a few swirls and a thin collar. Some splotchy lace is left behind.

S: Coffee beans, toasted malts and light milk chocolate. There is a dryness to the coffee bean smells.

T: Sugar sweetness, bigger roasted coffee bean, oaty malts and some slight roast.

M: Medium bodied, the carbonation was a little to lively more for me and didn¬ít let the flavors really coat the palate.

O: Very solid and rich in flavor. The carbonation needs to be a tad lower for me though.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-04-2012

Clearish ruby-mahogany with an amazing aroma of roasty easpresso, cinnamon pancakes, and a light touch of vanilla. Taste is really delicious and really cool. You get this cool wave of manageable espresso tones, followed by some light tobacco tones, sweet dark maltiness, light vanilla, and light dark cocoa. Incredible.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2015 Very good coffee beer...nose is vanilla, dark roast malts, dark chocolate, and lots of dark roast coffee.  Taste follows, but is very even handed.  Coffee predominates but well done.  Would be great with any braised meats or barbeque.

>>rerate...from bottle.  Lot of vanilla in nose and more vanilla and chocolate driven on taste.  Great with New Mexican red chili enchiladas and pork, and even ok with heavily cinnamoned Apple pie.

>>>rerate-extra from weezel. Can.  Bit sweeter than I remember.  Lots of vanilla, creamy.

Bottle: &nbsp Burnt brown sugar brown, moderate sudsy tannish head, spotty lacing. &nbsp Fairly assertive coffee aroma, a little cream and sugar as well. &nbsp Heh, smells like cold coffee. &nbsp Smooth semi-sweet maltiness up front, a little chalky in the back. &nbsp Flavors of coffee beans, cocoa, and bakers chocolate. &nbsp Tastes fairly good, and has a clean finish. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are moderate. &nbsp Finishes with a soft hop bite. &nbsp Lingering coffee notes. &nbsp Very respectable beer! &nbsp Thanks for the bottle Jason!
Bottle at James¬í a few months ago. Thanks James. Dark, red-brown pour. Aroma is nutty. Taste is of dry coffee and roast. Medium-bodied with not a lot of aftertaste.

On tap at the brewery. Wow! Strong coffee nose, smells like freshly-ground roasted beans, with some maltinesss. Copper-brown color. Flavors: good coffee again, roasty, some caramel. The coffee is well-integrated, tasty, and doesn¬ít go too harsh, not over-boiled, even though this is a light style. Thin body. The most coffee-like coffee beer I¬íve had. Not easy to do in a light style. Very very good.

Taken from old notes. Brown pour with little to no head. Nice aroma of coffee. Taste is the same up front then gently fades to the sweetness of the malt. Slight bitterness as well. Finish is typical brown ale.
12 oz bottle poured ni a snifter.  For a ¬ísmall¬í beer this was pretty good. Coffee aroma, taste even look, this was refreshing. I want more of this one!

Pours dirty cola brown color with a tan head which fades to deccent lacing.  aroma is sweet espresso, roasted malts, bakers coco, caramel, and some vanilla.  Taste is very nice with a lot of espresso, rosted malts, baker coco, caramel malts, chicory, vanilla, and some mild hop bitterness to balace out the malt profile.  has a medium body with a super creamy mouthfeel, and a mild black coffee bitter yet at the same time sweet finish.  overall, a world class brown ale that definitly belongs in the top three in the world.
black color, aroma of coffee, chocolate, vanilla, marshmallow, flavors of bitter coffee, roasted nuts, roasted malt, vanilla, slightly watery, very enjoyable

Bottle at Cervezas, Miami. It pours very dark cloudy brown, with a thin off-white head. The nose is cocoa powder, espresso coffee, hint of vanilla, marshmallow and toasted coconut. The taste is rich-roast coffee, roasted malt, nut, bitter dark chocolate, hint of vanilla and dark fruit, with a dry-roasted finish. Medium body and moderate, prickly carbonation. Well balanced. Not particularly complex, but very drinkable and flavoursome.

Tqp flight at the brewery  Light brown pour, minimal head. Aroma of sweet coffee.  Taste is similar. Thin in the mouth but well made and a flavorful session able beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. A dirty brown color, almost looks like dirty river water. Smell is rich with malt and coffee. Drinks very easy and is filled with coffee. Sweet, but not too sweet. A very good brown ale if you like coffee. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at RnH.  Dark cola color with a small tan head.  Awesome espresso bean and strong coffee aroma exudes from the glass with hints of dark chocolate commingled.  Initial flavor is all espresso beans followed by the sweetness and bitterness of bitter sweet chocolate.  Impressive mouthfeel as a palatable bitterness lingers in the mouth.  Truly enjoyable brown ale.
Great fresh espresso aroma wafts from a dark cola colored beer with a tan head. Tastes like a terrific cold brewed espresso but sweet dulce de leche caramel. So good.

Poured a thin 1 finger head that dissipates into a paper thin lining over the beer. Aroma of strong roasted coffee, sweet malts and a hint of dark chocolate. Taste follows the nose and then some. Freakin delicious! Coffee balances with malts well. Mouthfeel is right where I want it carbonation may be a little high but nothing crazy. Overall it¬ís an amazing coffee brown ale!

bottle thanks to smith4498
aroma, coffee very strong
color, dark,cream tan head
taste, like coffee, esperso, alttle carbonated for my taste though
overall, neat style
user_location: @RED BHUT JOIKIAS!, Paulsboro, New Jersey, USA

text:
Bottle via smith4489   Ok, so I just poured about 2oz of this beer into a pint glass and it literally filled the rest of the glass with an enormous, rediculously large, obnoxious head that just won¬ít go away. I mean, it¬ís been sitting for like 5 minutes now and it¬ís still there.  Wow.  It wasn¬ít even an agressive pour either.  So when the head dies down in about 10 more inures or so, I will finish the rating of this beer.  Please be patient while we wait.

------- minutes go by (literally)-----& I attempt to pour the rest of the beer into the glass, I realize that this just isn¬ít gonna happen without creating excessive amounts of head.  This beer is ridiculous.  Is it purposely carbonated this much?  Is this normal for the beer?  If so, why?  This is the most carbonated beer I have ever seen.  

Eventually, I get it all 12oz into a 16oz pint glass, but not without taking brakes every 3-4oz and letting the head die down.  The entire process of pouring the beer into a glass took like 15 minutes, I shit you not.  So now I¬ím ready to smell, taste and evaluate the beer.

Pours a deep amber-brown,  cloudy and I¬íve already described the ordeal with the head.  Aromas of coffee, but not just coffee, also toffee, caramel and some nice chocolate notes.  I¬ím getting a back room poker game, filled with hazy cigar smoke and seedy card sharks.  Nice aroma.

The taste follows suit, but not as coffee forward as I was expecting.  Smooth, roasty, but lacking something...  Don¬ít know exactly what I¬ím looking for here, but there¬ís something missing.  

Can¬ít give this beer the high rating that everyone else has... It just doesn¬ít meet the high expectations that everyone else has set for it.  Thanks Jason.

Bottle. Coffee, chocolate, vanilla and some light earthy/smoky aroma. Murky cola brown with a small tan head. Tastes like it smells.. chocolate,  earthy ash, coffee, vanilla flavor. Light to medium body. Dry ashy / bitter finish.

(trade w/Changeup45) - 12oz bottle - Slightly tan foamy head. Body looks like Cola. Delicate aroma of ground coffee. Watery mouthfeel. Unmistakable flavor of ground up twigs..er I mean chicory. It¬ís sort of like an under ripe peach if you¬íve never experienced chicory coffee. Brown ale comes out in the backbone, but only a bit. Glad I tried it. Glad I didn¬ít get a six-pack. :-)

Originally reviewed: 6/16/09. Poured from a 32oz. growler, received from the excellent trader, Kiefdog. Thanks, Kevin!

This wasn¬ít the prettiest of beers right off. Pours a more ruby-brown with about a half inch of tan head on top. Retention was zilch, and there was no lacing whatsoever. That is definitely an expendable weakness though, because this beer was stellar on all other counts. 

This smelled like freshly ground coffee, chocolate, muffins, brownies, and finished with a roasted woodsy character. Wow. I want to dip my whole face in this beer. The mouthfeel is creamy and smooth, with just enough of a carbonation kick to let you know she¬ís fresh. Moderate amount of bubbles rising through. 

As I sip, my mouth is filled with everything I like about a good morning meal. Huge coffee presence that warms and soothes. Following this is a mild breadiness that finishes sweet and satisfying. There¬ís definite bitterness in here that is pleasant, but the sweetness and the coffee are kings. This is an excellent brown. I realize that it is limited in its release, but get some if you can.

Bottle with James, Andrew, and Maggi. Pours a coke brown with a little head. Aroma is straight day old coffee grinds. Taste is surprisingly sweet and syrupy, but really rounded. Hard to have this level of complexity in a brown ale.

In short: A smooth nutty brown ale with a medium amount of fresh ground coffee.  Good
How: Bottle 12oz.  Consumed when ?? months of age.  Bottle sent by ??, thanks ??.  Ok, so this was probably an extra and I don¬ít remember where it comes from so I¬ím not entirely sure how fresh/old the bottle was
The look: Mahogany body topped by a small beige head
In long: Nose has plenty of fresh tobacco leafs, light smoky notes, caramelized walnuts, a medium amount freshly ground coffee.  Taste is soft brown whole-wheat bread, walnuts, caramel, fresh coffee, some vanilla, chewing on a cigar, whip cream.  The leafy hops do their balancing job behind the scene because the beer doesn¬ít feel sweet and there is not much bitterness.  The coffee is there no doubt, but for a beer with the word ¬ìespresso¬î in the name the coffee part is not overwhelming.  This is a decent beer but somehow the type of flavor quickly gets tiresome, with every sip I liked the beer less and less, and that was only a 12oz bottle.  I¬ím taking off points for low drinkability, a 5.5% brown ale should be more sessionnable that this.  I don¬ít know why I keep trying these CCB beers even if I don¬ít like them, nor do I know why I keep looking in the toilet when I flush even though I¬íve never seen anything exciting in there too.

Bottle.  Mild aroma consisting of mostly black coffee.  Flavor is a nice mixture of heavy coffee, bitter chocolate, and light vanilla.  Soft palate and smooth finish.  It improves exponentially as it warms.  A pretty damn good brown ale.
UPDATED: APR 4, 2014 Med brown, aroma of coffee, little bit of vanilla and some maduro nuttiness.  Soft, creamy, lots of coffee kicks in, a little nutty and slightly sweet.
Aroma has a very distinct coffee smell.  Very dark black appearance.  Smooth but semi bitter taste.  Too much of a coffee aftertaste for me.

From notes. Pours a rich black with a thin tan head that leavs very thin lacing. 
Bam! Strait up face In a bag of espresso beans aroma. Nice smells of roasty malt and dark chocolate.
Taste is awesome. Lots of espresso, some cocoa in the body and a very nice bitter finish. Very roasty with some nice lingering sweetness. 
Mouthfeel leaves just a bit of stickiness. Pretty light body with a medium level of carbonation. Really nice.

Draft at taproom. Deep dark brown, stable beige head and scattered laces. Aroma too much coffee extract, coffee dessert, not balanced by roast. Flavors follow, with a lot of creamy sweetness. Like coffee flavored chocolate/mocha cake. It's drinkable and tasty but not compelling as a beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Very nice flavor. Has a vanilla flavor to it and very smooth.                                      

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle 33cl, trade. Pours cloudy brown amber with a huge tanned head leaving lace. Aroma is lots of coffee malty toasted a bit sweet and chocolate. Flavor is as aroma, a bit acidy bitter and fruity. Finishes bitter fruity with a good coffee touch.

12 oz. bottle, sent from Glouglouburp (thanks Dany), pours an opaque dark brown with a reddish tinge and a small beige head. Aroma certainly brings espresso beans to the forefront, with some dark fruit, chicory and carob. Flavour of bitter espresso beans, sort of a metallic toasted malt and dark fruit. The espresso begins nicely, but sort of tapers off and finished metallic and nastily astringent. Thin palate with little depth. Disappointed by this one.
brown in color, clear with a thin tan head.  Nice brown ale malt mixed with coffee and chocolate aroma and flavors. Easy drinking brew with a fantastic flavor.

Tap at CCB. Nose is straight up coffee with a hint of chocolate. All roast. Pour is dark brown with a thin head. Taste is also straight up coffee. Loads of roast and some slight chocolate. Thin mouthfeel with a dry finish. This beer has the most coffee I¬íve ever tasted/smelled in any beer so far.

enjoyed out of a glass poured from a 12oz bottle. deep dark brown in the glass with a thin tan head that fades fast. dry earthy aroma of coffee beans, cocoa and some roasted malt. the texture is smooth. flavor is malty and of coffee with some cocoa and hints of vanilla mixed in. i¬ím not a coffee drinker but will make an exception for this!
Bottle: Poured a dark brown with thick light brown head. Aroma is loads of coffee. Taste is metal and stale coffee.

Bottle.  Pours clear brown with a medium, fizzy tan head, medium retention with good lacing.  Aroma is earthy and spicy coffee, chocolate, cookie, and dark fruity esters.  Flavor is malt forward with earthy coffee, light chocolate, and hops with a dry finish.  Medium body, warmth and carbonation.

Bottle. Pours clear brown with frothy light beige head; short retention and spare lacing. Aroma is ashy, dry chocolate, espresso, and deep earthy notes. Flavor is smooth coffee/espresso taste throughout, light caramel malt, with a subtle leathery hop taste; dry, ashy finish. Medium body and carbonation with low warmth.

Dark brown beer with an off-white, frothy head. Strong aromas of dark coffee, and dark licorice. Tastes of straight dark coffee, dark chocolate notes, cardboard, and some traces of coffee beans. Bittersweet coffee finish does not deliver any of the vanilla flavors promised. I did not like this one too much, but it is still a tasty brown ale. Just be in the mood for coffee, not beer when you reach for this one.

Bottle courtesy of Doodler (thanks Scot) poured a clear reddish brown with a lasting tan head. Aromas of carmel, coffee, earthiness and light cocoa. Palate was light to medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of coffee, cocoa and light carmel with a smooth lingering coffee finish.

Clear brown pour, small white head. The aroma is bold and in your face.  Huge raw espresso, smoke, and tobacco with some roasted nuts for good measure.  Light mouthfeel, solid carb. The finish is surprisingly light, with a light bitterness. Touches of espresso with cream, and even a bit of vanilla in the finish. Nice stuff!

Strong Aroma of hot espresso and sugar, flavor starts like a strong coffee, then subsides into a smooth sweet malty brown beer. The cocoa comes in like a Mexican hot chocolate on the end. Aroma is hot, flavor and Mouthfeel are cool.

12oz bottle.(brown ale w/ vanilla, cacoa & coffee beans) I am under the impression that their Maduro brown is one of the best brown ales made, so I am excited for this version. Nose of espresso and to a lesser extent, chocolate. Stong coffee flavor with vanilla, chocolate and dark caramel, maybe some herbal hops lingering in the background. Full bodied, intially, but finishes nicely balanced. Creamy. The extra flavorings seem to take center stage in this beer, but do not overpower it. Another fine offering from CCB.

Bottle. Sweet chocolate and caramel notes. Light coffee notes. Dark brown to mahogany with very no head. Beautiful flavor with sweet creamy coffee and caramel tones. Good body, not especially heavy but stands up to the heavier flavors. Highly drinkable and very expressive.
12 ounce bottle. The aroma starts with a spicy coffee nose, then the sweet vanilla cuts through and balances the aromas. The flavors of coffee and vanilla play well off of one another.
Tap at brewery.  This is incredibly delicious brew.  Smells of delicious espresso.  Tastes of perfect espresso, and some caramel, vanilla, and malt.  Light wood and bitter on finish.

Bottle.  Pours a very thick, black color w/ a tan head.  The dominant aroma and flavor is tha of coffee, as expected.  Surprisingly, not heavily bodied.  Light to medim.  Coffee aftertaste hangs around.  Still good though.

Hands down the BEST coffee-infused beer I¬íve ever tasted.  I¬ím a  big fan of Kona Brewing Company¬ís "Pipeline Porter", however CCB¬ís Cubano Espresso blows Pipeline away.  The aroma is heavenly, the taste is sublime, and the color is gorgeous.  It of course has the expected coffee flavor, however the kicker for me was the unexpected hint of chocolate.  Made for one very happy palette, indeed. I almost wish this were available as a ¬ínear-beer¬í so that I may enjoy it daily for breakfast :]
Thin as can be.  You do get a heavy hit of espresso.  A very nice easy drinker.

12 oz bottle served in a tulip.  Pour is deep mahogany with 4 billowing fingers of kaki head that stuck to the glass like glue.  Nose is huge chicory, campfire smoke, cigars, espresso, brown sugar, and fresh cut tobacco leaves.  Taste is very close to the nose, and believe it or not, leaves me feeling like I just puffed on a sweet cigar!  This is a very enjoyable brew, though far from the top of my list for delicious brown ales.  This is more of a niche brew for something unique and tasty.
Pours dark brown with a tan head.  Aroma of espresso, roasted malt.  Very nice coffee flavor although the body seemed just a touch thin.  Well done.

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2012 Pours a hazy dark brown with a beige head and aroma of espresso and coffee. Taste is wonderful, heavy coffee throughout, with flavors of roasted malts present as well. A very good coffee brew with a lot of flavor, probably the most coffee taste/aroma I¬íve seen in a beer

Dark brown handsome appearance, with a strong coffee aroma. Tastes like a cold cup of coffee, smooth with a medium to heavy body. No bitterness, a wonderful finish....with a small lingering coffee taste. No taste of alocol with the ABV at 5.5. Quite tasty and once again CCB proves itself as one of the
premier craft breweries. Bravo !

pours dark brown with a thin white head and some spotty lacing.  aroma is coconut, coffee, brown sugar, a hint of smoke, and some distant hoppiness.  taste is rich and dominated by a fruity coffee taste.  wood, pine and maple take over after the coffee makes its statement.  finish is sweet and sticky.  a nice beer but I just cant seem to get into the coffee beers despite my affinity for coffee itself.

This poured a murky muddy brown color with a biege head. Aroma was lots and lots of unroasted coffee and peppers, very odd. Flavor was again much the same, very bitter and peppery but not really roasted, also a little sour on the finish. Not what I was expecting from this one, but gets points for being unique.

Strong espresso/coffee aroma allows little else to reach your senses. Taste is more coffee than you would expect, meant in a positive way coming from a coffee lover. Slightly thick, but not enough to take away from anything. All in all, it¬ís possible to forget you¬íre not actually drinking an iced coffee, especially after enough of ¬íem. I was surprised how good this was.
Pours A dark brown with mild head. Nice roasted malt taste with a strong coffee after taste. A little smokey with hints of butter scotch.

Ar- The aroma is vanilla, malted chocolate balls, very pleasant espresso.

Ap- The body of the beer is mahogany. Thin white head resolves to a thin sheen. 

T- The flavor of the beer flashes bitter espresso going into a sweetened caramel, vanilla and cocoa. 

P- The body of the beer is light and well carbonated. A bit of slickness noted.

O-  A very well done brown ale with a nice espresso kick. If this is a sign of what Cigar City does I am looking forward to some more.

A dark, ruby-tinted, brown pour. I could only pour half the 12oz. bottle as the head quickly rose up. It¬ís still rising, forming a big peak of foam well outside the lip of my glass. Huge coffee aroma in the head. I¬íll wait a few minutes to see what else I get from it. Still waiting about 10 minutes later after pouring a couple more ounces in. Still a big dry coffee aroma. It smells like pouring coffee into the basket. A little too one-dimensional. Smells good though. Would be good for breakfast. Tastes like drinking a coffee. With a bit of sharp bitterness to boot. A little bit of burnt chocolate as well. A tinge of sourness. I think this one is a little infected. As evidenced by the non-stop foaming. Not the best beer I¬íve had from CCB, but it won¬ít stop me from trying more. Maybe.
not my favorite coffee or brown beer. roasty coffee aroma and flavor. light brown with nice white head.

12oz bottle I picked up at Connecticut Ave Wine in DC.  Pours a translucent, mahogany brown with a thin, eggshell head.  Nose is brown sugar, coffee grounds, a little nutty, some dark toast, a strong apple aroma.  Flavor is sweet, apples, brown sugar, pear, light coffee, a little nut, some cake icing, a little stale bread.  Strikes me as being infected.  There¬ís a strong apple cider flavor and aroma that seems out of place.  The coffee flavors come in at the very end and are a little watery.  Watery, finish over all.  There are dozens of better coffee beers out there.

Thanks to someone for sharing this bottle at the Flying Saucer Beer Tasting.

The beer pours  a brownish color with a white head. The aroma is heavy on the bitter coffee and bitter chocolate with a little bit of roasted malt mixed in. 

The flavor is more of the same. I get a lot of milk chocolate notes, with a good amount of coffee also mixed in. I also get some vanilla and hazelnut notes, as well as a little bit of cream.

Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.
(bottle) deep brown with tan head. Coffee aroma. Flavor of roast malt, coffee, chocolate.

Extreme dark brown with a massive tan froth that simply wont go away. Fantastic. The nose holds tons of earthen espresso grounds, bakers chocolate, chicory, tobacco, and a hint of milk chocolate. A flavor holds massive roasty cocoa nib, milky chocolate, and hints of dark fruits. The palate is medium to full with low carbonation and a roasty finish.

Beautiful deep walnut brown pour with a vivacious frothy head. Nose is delightful; notes of tobacco, chicory, coffee grounds, bitter chocolate, date, fig, and plum. Flavor is marked by really nice creamy lactic sugar, sweet coffee, milk chocolate, and a touch of spice. Palate is creamy and smooth with fitting medium carbonation. Really a solid beer.

Pours an opaque dark brown with a medium sized tan/lt mocha head...nice lacing.  Aroma has loads of coffee...hints of chocolate and nuttiness.  Flavor is very roasty...earthy and nutty with definite espresso flavor...a bit more hoppy than expected.  Mouthfeel is silky and lively and the finish lingers with roasty espresso.

12oz bottle. Poured a relatively clear ruby/reddish brown color with a small tan head. Aroma was bitter coffee notes, with a solid roasted malt character to it. Taste was bitter coffee, slightly sweet malt notes (like a standard brown ale). This was okay, but certainly not as exciting as I had hoped.
Bottle at Yespr¬ís - Thanks. Cloudy brown - offwhite head. Coffee, kaffe erstatning, grainy, cocoa, light nutty, herbal, light coffee, ok malty, soapy. Nice.

Bottle at yespr.
Hazy orange brown coloured with a solid medium sized beige head.
Sweet and light roasted aroma of berries, coffee and caramel.
Light roasted flavour of coffee, berries and caramel with notes of chocolate.
Light roasted finish.

Bottled. A hazy dark brown beer with a lazing dark brown beer. The aroma has notes of coffee, malt, and caramel. The flavor is sweet with notes of coffee, chocolate, roasted matl, and a bit of wood, leading to a dry coffee finish. Thanks yespr for sharing.
33 cL bottle. Pours hazy amber with a small tan head. Aroma is spiced, herbal and cold coffee. Citric and milky. Dense coffee herbal and spiced dry finish.

Bottle 35,5 cl. Courtesy of yespr. Pours a reddish amber with a slight haze and a lacing beige head. The nose has some cabbage at first but then comes the Espresso roast rushing in. Medium body, very roasty with a distinct edge of coffee. Very subtle and short finish with no real hoppiness. 290911

cloudy brown, large smooth light brown head.
aroma of coffee powder, roasted coffee, malts. quite dusty aroma.
flavor is chocolate, espresso, something resembling sawdust a bit watery..

Draught @ Cypress Street.  Dark brown pour with an off white head, good lace.  Aroma was huge, fresh roasted coffee grounds, bits of cocoa too.  Flavors were right on point with the aroma, big coffee notes, lingered forever.  Mouth was a bit thin but it worked.  Made for a super drinkable, big time flavored brown.  Excellent stuff.

A solid coffee brown ale. An nose a color of espresso. A tinny bit of white head which fades fast and leaves no lacing. A good representative of the style. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Botella, courtesy of Plovmand. Nice dark brown colour, light brown like head, creamish, nice. Pleasant roasty malty espresso chocolate aroma. Good mouthfeel indeed. Pleasant flavour of roasty malt and coffee with chocolate, peppery spice like too. Very nice.
I love this beer. Pours a light brown. Aroma of coffee, like a used coffee filter. The espresso flavor hits you ride away then you can taste the maduro brown on the back end.

12 oz bottle poured into a pint glass.  Pours a medium thin brown with a thick, creamy light tan head. Aromas of coffee and sour.  Taste is slightly sour, coffee richness, bitterness of the chicory, and some woody notes.  Body is medium, but thin, with average carbonation.  Overall, a very good brown ale

Bottled.  Poured deep ambery-brown with a creamy, sticky khaki head.. thorough lacing followed it down.  The aroma had a soft presentation of a lot of bold components for a brown ale.. sweet roasted coffee, slightly sour, greener coffee beans, nutty notes, and a hint of ash were present.. really enjoying it so far!  The flavor found more sourness than I¬íd like, mostly coffee-inspired.. sweet coffee, vanilla, and nutty notes around.. mild, dry scorched earth toward the back, along with more coffee roast.  Light-medium bodied and too well carbonated on the palate.. sourness and something akin to oxidation take away from the feel a little.. overall a very good brew that I¬íd love a keg of in my basement.

12 oz bottle from Decanted.   Pours deep brown/black in colour, with nice frothy tan head.  This beer is too much for me, but, wow, tonnes of aromas and tastes.  Expresso is there, roasted/burnt malt, burnt dark chocolate, etc. Also, Cigar City seems to use a ESB-ish yeast for all of their beers I¬íve tried, seems to be here too.  Not a fan, but would recommend to those who love the style.

Bottle. Thanks you Hopscotch for providing. Pours brown with a creamy light tan head. The aroma is espresso coffee, tobacco, light roasted and light chocolate.The flavour is coffee, roasted malt, light tobacco and dried fruit. Easy to drink but very flavorful.
Bottle, pours dark brown with small light brown head.... the aroma is espresso, milk chocolate, roasted...... the flavor is espresso, roasted malt..... medium body... with a dry coffee finish.....

Good brown; aroma of malts with SLIGHTEST coffee, vanilla?  Taste was subdued - I didn¬ít taste much coffee but a smoth brown with hint of vanilla and alscohol.  ruby cola pour.  will try again - subdued is the word here.

Wounderful nose of coffees, one of the best brown ales i ever had!  Thanks Dak!  I know its a little thin, but it is only a brown ale style, so with that in mind its perfect.  Wish I counld get this all the time.

Bottle shared by badnewsbeers. Fiery dark orange-brown, sediment-laden body, thin dense tan head. Nose of coffee beans, vanilla, toast, and brown sugar; light. Weird, rather thin body with cocoa and coffee beans, sharp carbonation, and tannic berryskins; sharp and medicinal. Dry, thin, but still good.

This beer was courtesy of phisigben from a recent in person trade. Thanks Ben! This beer pours a medium bodied rich mahogany in color with ruby highlights and a one finger beige colored head. It looks a little lighter than I remember Maduro. It smells like Big Sound, of all things, mixed with a shot of espresso. It gives aromas of chocolate, sweet malt, cream, with a light coffee bitterness. The flavors presented are dark roasted malt with a touch of bitter coffee. The chocolate doesn¬ít come in as well as it did in the nose and the overly appealing scotch esque malt isn¬ít present either. The flavor is also short lived and not as strong as it could or should be. It drinks a little thin, and thinner than Maduro and just doesn¬ít feature the same complexity as the base beer. Overall it¬ís a solid beer, but Maduro is far superior in my opinion.

4oz pour @ Cigar City Sample 9of12. Pours mahogany body with a small beige head. Aroma of coffee, roasted malt, caramel, and chocolate. Flavor of coffee, roasted malt, and chocolate with a dry, bitter finish.

Had higher expectations for this one.  Nose and flavor are similar.  The coffee flavor is definitely bold cuban coffee, but it starts to taste and smell like coffee grounds.  There is a slight sourness that doesnt really go with what the beer should be in my opinion.  Like the Maduro itself im not a huge fan but its still interesting and a decent drink.
Intense coffee aroma and flavors. A little thinner than the regular jose marti porter. Some of the tartness comes through after my palate adjusts

Bottle; Pour is dark brown with a khaki head. Earthy coffee beans on the nose, caramel - this is interesting. It¬ís not really what I was expecting either; Bitter coffee beans, caramel, ash; This is an interesting mix - it¬ís light bodied but so dripping in (coffee) flavor.

12 ounce can

Halfway through the stash of Cigar City beers I moved next to this beer. It was not quite what I expected. While not a terrible release and certainly well made it didn¬ít spark the same enthusiasm as some of the others. Even so it was a noble experiment that was ideally made.

Aroma and appearance - The inky black beer was graced by a gentle mocha head. Tendrils of light clear lacing provided evidence of the pour¬ís longevity. Fresh ground coffee beans were overpowering. Masking the other aspects I think this is what put me off the beer. It is so strong that this smells almost like a porter rather than a brown ale.

Flavor and palate - A heavy rush of espresso hits the tongue. So strong it masks everything else there is no room for the usual flavors that I associate with the style. The lingering aftertaste left a strong mark. Overall this was solid but one dimensional. I think other styles might be accented; this one is just buried by the extra ingredients.

Pours a clear brown with a white white. Nose is freshly pressed coffee, hints of chocolate and vanilla. Flavor is medium bodied with roasted coffee and chocolate and sweetness. Very delicious and packed full of flavor.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of Dalzale, thanks Greg.  dark brown pour with a light khaki head which doesn¬ít last long.  aroma of chocolate and coffee.  flavor is a nice blend of malts with subtle coffee and chocolate notes.  low carbonation and rather thin body.  nice coffee beer.

Bottle. Very dark opaque brown with cola highlights around with a minimally lasting eggshell head. Lots of coffee in the aroma, roasted malts, nuttiness, and some slight earth.  Nice coffee presence, but it doesn¬ít overwhelm...nice savory nutty qualities, bit of a malty sweetness in the middle but not much, some light chocolate in the finish.  Lighter to medium body with medium carbonation.

holy god in heaven, this is freaking impressive. coffee, cocoa, dark Karo syrup, molasses, butterscotch and nuttiness with a milk stout like character. i couldnt drink a lot of them, but it makes a great beer to go with a dessert.

Aroma: roasty, chocolate, earthy and tobacco notes, coffee.  Pours deep brown, tan head with average retention.  Flavor follows the nose, I find a very distinct tobacco note, also lots of coffee and light roast.  Slightly bitter, balanced towards the malt and coffee, nice crisp and dry finish.  Medium body and carbonation.

Pours a rich mahogany with a thin light tan head. Delicious dark roasted espresso bean aroma. Also casual notes of chocolate and nuts. Flavor is gourmet coffee through and through. Sweet caramel and somewhat chocolatey background balanced perfectly by the natural bitterness of the espresso. Better than my morning cup of joe. Palate is a little thin, but other than that this is a delightful to drink. Thanks for the trade Jason.

12oz bottle courtesy of smith4498. thanks, jason! pours a dark, cloudy brown with a thin, creamy off-white head leaving light lacing. aroma is a fantastic blend of pure, cuban coffee, mocha espresso, and raw, chocolate malts backed by earthy hops, a touch of vanilla, and toasted coffee beans. flavor is delicious as well with dry, rich, roasted espresso, toasted nuts, mocha, and hints of oatmeal backed by a touch of caramel, chicory wood, and light, herbal, earthy hops. palate is lighter bodied and very smooth with a dry, roasted finish. overall, a great brown ale.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2013 Poured nice and dark, with a thick head from the vigorous pour. The smell was strong of coffee, dark chocolate and a touch of smokiness with some vanilla in the background. The flavor was impressive (and I¬íve had quite a few coffee beers). Strong notes of well-roasted coffee, burnt almost.. With strong notes of chocolate and a lingering smokiness all around - layer by layer of flavor brings a nice complexity. Leaves the bitter finish of a fresh cup of black coffee in the morning. Definitely a sipper and well rounded drink ---> CCB does it again :-).

4 pack bottled on May 27, 2011 purchased from Five Points Bottle Shop. This is honestly one of the best coffee beers I have ever had. The milder qualities of this brown ale allow the coffee to come through more than a fuller bodied stout or porter would. Cigar City has achieved that real whole bean aroma and flavor. It¬ís so well rounded, more like chewing on a chocolate covered bean than drinking a cup of brewed coffee. Palate is pretty slick and just medium weight. If you love coffee, you will go nuts over this one.

Bottle from my secret santa.  Brown in color with some small ruby highlights.  A small off white head rests atop.  Maybe a touch lighter in color than I would like, but still this looks the part of a brown ale.  Cocoa puffs dominate the aroma with a bit of coffee appearing too.  Very sweet aroma.  Taste is sweet cocoa, some cream notes, with a small bit off coffee been being present.  Finish is slightly astringent.  Almost reminds me of a watery, sweet, cold-pressed coffee.  Fairly light bodied, and a tad thin.  It does leave a lot of lacing on the glass, though.  A little disappointing to be honest, but I can see how this beer could be really good when it is on.

(12oz bottle) Pours a ruby/clear red/brown color with a tan head.  Nice carbonation.  Aroma is bitter coffe and a bit of malt sweetness.  Taste follows suit with bitterness domination.  Thin bodied with an oily texture. Huge bitter finish.  This beer could have used more sweetness to give it some more balance.  I didn¬ít enjoy this one much.

Sample at the tap room. This beer is a dark coffee brown color with a thin beige head that recedes quickly. Stringy lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasted coffee beans and malt. Medium body with a rich coffee character underscored by charred wood and dark chocolate. The finish is roasty with a lingering black coffee aftertaste. Very good beer overall.

I had this pour just after a pint of Jai Alai, and I have to say... my palate was overwhelmed.  I will try it again on its own sometime, but the fact that it was such an overload actually made me feel that this beer was flawed.  What do you get with it?  Roasted, almost smoke... caramel (charred), almost a molasses, malt, nut (hazel) and coffee, coffee, coffee.  Bitter finish, alcohol undertone, and a loaf of dark bread as it lays across the tongue.  Maybe I¬ím not being fair, but it was just so much to deal with.  For all my negativity, I can admit that it smelled/looked sexy as hell, and had a good palate.

text: 12 oz. bottle via sendsilk.  Pours brown with a large beige head.  The aroma is rich coffee with notes of caramel and chicory spice.  The flavor is quite interesting: the rich coffee, caramel and chicory come through right from the start.  The finish leaves a pipe tobacco sensation that reminds me of trying my grandfathers pipes when I was a little kid.  Regardless, this puts an interesting spin on your standard brown al that is refreshing to see.

Pours dark brown, with a small tan head. Aroma of coffee, and the coffee flavor is amazing at the end of the beer, with no noticeable hop flavor.  Really good, and will be a mainstream in my fridge going forward.
Pours dark copper brown with thin tan head.  Aroma was vanilla, espresso beans, chocolate and roastyness.  Taste was sweet espresso with a chocolate finish.  Smooth and balanced.

On tap at Capone¬ís during Cigar City Philly Beer Week event with Leafs93 and O¬íMeara.  Pours deep brown color with a caramel colored head.  Has an aroma of coffee and malt.  Very espresso forward a nice dry layer and chocolate note on the finish.  Damn tasty.

I poured a 12 oz bottle into a snifter. This was quite fresh - dated May 2011  - and it raised a one-finger khaki head above the deep russet body. The head faded to virtually nothing, although the beer did lace the glass. All of the chicory appears concentrated in the nose, as the flavor mostly yield coffee and caramel. Like all the CCB beers I have had, this combines these flavors into a beer of peerlessly smooth texture. Overall, this is an excellent beer, packing as much flavor as a big stout into a drinkably balanced body, and relying on the coffee to balance out the malt sweetness rather than setting the beans at war with big hops. Another winner from the folks in Tampa.

Pours deep brown with coffee and malt notes.  The coffee drives and lingers while you still get a nice dry hint of chicory with a light note of cocoa.  You get a decent feel of the malt backbone as well.
Taster from 12-ouncer displays sparkling clarity in root beer brown. Exhibits tobacco aroma, a lean body and a sweet finish.

12 ounce thanks to 	smith4498. That¬ís a big shot of coffee! The brown ale gets over-powered by a porter, coffee tasting shot. Not a Cuban coffee, as my memories tell me from growing up in Miami, but a nice beer!

Bottle thanks to Mike.  Pours a dark brown with a touch of red and a very thick, frothy tan head which laces it way down the sides of the glass.  Aroma is earthy expresso, light bitter chocolate, coffee grind, and a slight creaminess.  Smells great!  Taste is expresso up front followed by a somewhat dry combination of coffee, bitter chocolate, tobacco (?), and a slight bit of thin malt.  This is a really well done beer and has a ton of character and body for 5.5%.  Excellent work Cigar City!

12 oz bottle courtesy of Dan, tasted side-to-side with the Bolita Brown Double Nut Brown Ale at a tasting with Chris and Dan. Served in a goblet. Pours hazy reddish brown with a small tan head. The head fades to a thin remnant but leaves no lace. The nose is a very nice combination of coffee, smoke, chocolate and earth. The flavour is moderately sweet with smoke and coffee notes. The finish is short and fairly clean. On the palate, it is medium in body with a smooth, creamy texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a very nice smokey, roasted brown ale. It is smooth and easy drinking, but also respectably complex. Very well done. 2011-04-16

Draft at Blind Tiger while on business trip to New York City in November 2010.  This was the first Cigar City brew I ever tried, and currently shows as the #1 brown ale in the world on RateBeer.  Very dark in the bar, but when put next to a candle, it reveals brown with some red and only a thin head.  Aroma is dominated by dark earthy organic just-ground-before-brewing coffee.  Also some smoke, some dark chocolate, and some cocoa powder.  Flavor is also full of earthy coffee, but quite smooth like a little bit of milk or cream is in the coffee..perhaps some chicory coffee which reminds me of growing up in southern Louisiana.  The coffee is very forward in this one, but it has the lightness in body of a brown ale.  (190, 499)

Very smooth, almost like drinking brown ale flavored coffee, only this is the opposite.   Not earth shattering but respectable.   My second beer of 2011, thanks neighbor; code name for her will be Wisconsin Beer Angel.

On-tap at the pub as part of a taster... Pours a bright amber/copper color that is very clear. Much clearer and lighter in color than I would imagine of any beer called Cubano Espresso, making me think of a coffee color. A nice tan head, good retention and lacing... The aroma is really sweet, caramel with tons of fresh coffee. I really like this... The taste is really good, coffee forward for sure but the coffee the notes are sweet with lots of caramel and chocolate. Really smooth to drink with a hint of vanilla.

This was the shock of our taster and well worth trying. A big improvement on maduro.

This beer poured brown with a little head. Smells of coffee, malt, and sweet cream. It tastes like coffee and milk chocolate with some malt. very good beer, bitter sweet and a smooth finish. Would drink this for breakfast if it was socially acceptable.
Draft at the gate. Lookslikeyour standard brown ale. No head. Smells of coffee, malt and cocoa. Tastye is espresson a chocolate on the lighyter side wih a crisp aftertaste. Awesome beer

12oz bottle.  Pours a deep coffee brown with a 2 finger thick off white head.  Great nose of spicy espresso beans, toasted malts and a bit of cocoa.  Big bitter coffee flavor with assertive espresso bitterness in the finish.  Another awesome brew from CC.
Bottle thanks to Solan. Pale brown complexion with a nice head. Aroma is coffee and cream with a slight smokiness to it. Flavor is robust with notes of chicory.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2011 To date this is the greatest beer I have tasted. It was something special. I would say this isnt really a beer drinkers beer but it has an amazing tasted. If starbucks brewed a beer this is what they would want it to taste like. I had this one on tap at the brewery and it helped to make my trip there unforgetable. This beer was amazing. It pours a kind of light but yet dark brown colour. very light carbination. at the front it tastes of espresso and it finishes with a light maltyness a bit of caramel notes in there. It was the prefect mix of espresso and beer tastes, which are my 2 favorite drinks, could be why I liked it so much. If your ever able to try this and havent it is very much worth the try. I was very sadly unable to find any bottles of this on my trip to florida, although that may have been a good thing because I would have bought as much as I could find.

Bottle. Pours brown with a nice off-white head. Aroma of milk chocolate, nuts, vanilla, and yes some coffee/espresso. Flavor is very espresso heavy with a bit a chalky chocolate component and a nice chicory note. Very good.

If it¬ís not gonna be a hoppy brown ale, might as well make it a coffee brown ale.  Seriously.  Not that we can get Cubano-Style Espresso Brown Ale in Charleston anyway, but my other favorite Brown, the hop beast from Duck-Rabbit, is also nowhere to be found in this part of SC.  Why must we suffer from a lack of good browns?  Can¬ít even get Dogfish Brown.  Stupid distributors.
Anyway, this beer rocks.  Coffee is good.  Brown ale is good.  Coffee brown ale is good.

12oz bottle my brother picked up while in Tampa, thanks Jeff! Pours a deep, hazed, brown colored body with some amber highlights. Finger-width, dense and frothy, brown head that dissipates slowly and leaves a nice lacing throughout. Aroma is lightly toasted caramels and pungent, but not overpowering espresso. Pretty fresh smelling coffee too. Nuts, some grain, spice, a light earth, a touch of ashy cocoa, and a hint of vanilla. Flavor is similar. Soft and fresh, bitter espresso up front with a light cocoa and some lightly toasted caramels. More nuts and grain along with a light earthy spice follows. Nutty vanilla grows slightly into the finish as does some roast and earthy spice. Coffee mellows a bit allowing a light earthy bitterness and lightly sweetened caramel and cocoa to come out more. Finishes smooth and slowly dries before leaving a fairly lengthy aftertaste. Medium-light, very smooth body with a soft, medium, somewhat creamy carbonation. Overall, a pretty solid brown. Very easy drinking and well balanced. I like the light earthy spice and not at all overpowering espresso bitterness blending well with the cocoa and caramel. Good one.

Pours reddish brown, thin off white head, thanks Caleb.  Aroma has nice notes of sweet chocolate, coffee, some roast and sweet caramel.  Taste is like a mocha, coffee and chocolate mixing well into some brown sugar, finishing slightly roasted and nutty.  Pretty good brown ale!

Ahh my first Cigar City beer--I have to say it lived up to the hype and satisfied my craft thirst.  Big nose of espresso beans poured an amber bown color with a shorter head--smells very tasty.  Thin lace throughout and the flavor was of balanced coffee and malts w/a nice bite of espresso to it.  Bitterness of coffee flavors but not too huge or over the top--just right.  Taste just how it smells.  Good balance and not too extreme.  A great brown ale

Bottle via changeup45. Thanks man!  Pours dark brown with ruby highlights.  Nice solid and dense sheet of light tan suds atop.  Vibrant nose full of coffee and cocoa with an underlying sweetness pushing the fumes up your nose.  Flavors again bring back the coffee and chocolate flavors, adding a little acidicness to experience, and leaving the mouth with a very vivid mocha-like flavor that seems to linger for quite a while...which here is a good thing.  Body is thin for me, but it¬ís a brown ale and is inevitable, so I¬ím not complaining.  Good brown ale though for sure.

Bottle sample thanks to CLevar!  Light brown pour, some floaties, minimal carbonation and an aroma of sweet chocolate and a little coffee.  Flavor is earthy bitter chocolate, a good malt base and finishes a little thin.  Very good.

bottle. dark burgundy body, dark tan quick head.  nose overtaken by forceful dark fruit, gelatin, dark fruit gelatin, forcibly sweet caramel malt.  coffee? perhaps in a caramel-chocolate square piece you purchase at your local chocolatier.  smells like candy.  first taste is a combination of mild carbonation froth and somewhat rough malt, dissolving with medium-high bitterness across a drying and bitter finish.  the coffee character seems suspended above the malt, making itself felt most strongly in the finish, but clashing with bitterness.  hearty, rounded, chewy malt texture, though not as overbearing as some of their previously sampled beers.

12oz bottle. Having had a few Cigar City brown ales, I will preemptively say that this is my least favorite - not because it¬ís a bad beer, but just because I don¬ít generally enjoy coffee beers. Pours a dark, cola-brown color; decent, light-tan head with modest retention and lacing. Lots of espresso notes and dark coffee roast in the aroma (nothing acrid, nothing particularly green), with a modest chocolaty core and some noticeable spiciness, presumably from the chicory addition. Honestly, that chicory note starts to stick out after a bit. Medium body; medium carbonation. Medium-high amounts of espresso beans, roasted coffee, and milk chocolate upfront; the spicy chicory note sits more quietly in the mouth; a very deep, delicious espresso coffee character that still melds well with the cola-like core brown ale without completely overshadowing it; the coffee addition is excellent, it just isn¬ít entirely my thing (I¬íd happily take the base beer in a heartbeat). Still, really tasty, and this is growing on me... very deep, rich espresso character. Lasting finish of toasted maltiness, along with rich darker chocolate and espresso; nicely dry.

A reddish copper brown ale with a thin superlacing moka head. In aroma, nutty malt overlayed with vanilla, coffee and sweet chocolate. In mouth, a smooth brown ale with sweet moka, quite beautiful, rich and balanced. On tap at brewery, Jan 5 2011.
bottle thanks to markwise.  Pours a dark brown with a tan head.  Nose is big-time espresso and some nut.  Taste is of espresso, nuts and tobacco.  Mouthfeel is medium-thin.

12oz bottle thanks to drowland!  Pours a dark ruby red/brown with a thin off white head,  aroma is of coffee, vanilla and a hint of chocolate, the flavor is very smooth and has coffee on the front end with delicious vanilla notes on the end, very good coffee brew, huge thanks to Danny!
Bottle.  Another good beer from Cigar City.  Not much I can add to the other 170 ratings of this beer.

Bottle. 12oz. Emptied into a snifter. Pours an amber brown with a slightly creamy, thin tan head that dissipated rather quickly. Aroma is very layered with espresso, roasty malt, and vanilla nut being the most prevalent. Secondary notes of chocolate and caramel. The mouthfeel on this beer was impressive, soft and balanced, that went down like a nice hot cup of joe. Flavor was no surprise with excessive amounts of high quality coffee, milk chocolate, and oatiness. Lacing was light and spotty. Smooth and roasty finish. Slightly warming in the bottom of stomach. Another excellent beer from one of my favorite brewers. If you like regular Maduro, you will def be a fan of this brew.

Finally found some of this in bottles. Pours a liquidy, dark color with little head. Aroma is of coffee and malt. Taste is lots of sweet coffee, malt and slight bitterness. Very thin in the palate. Overall an awesome beer.
12 oz. Bottle.  This was very enjoyable.  Thank you jwattsrugger.  Dark black pour.  Medium head.  Coffee in your face in the nose and start.  I get vanilla at the end.  A very well made beer.

Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a Duvel tulip.

Pours a very dark amber brown with a 1 finger creamy light tan head. Good lacing.

Smell: Espresso with light touches of chocolate and malt. It smells like I just walked into a coffee shop. Smells delicious.

Taste: Coffee is dominant throughout, which in this case is a very good thing. There are light touches of hops and chocolate in the middle and toasted malt at the finish. Aftertaste is mildly bitter with a typical coffee aftertaste. This is like drinking iced coffee.Extremely well-balanced and delicious.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied with a fairly high amount of carbonation. Goes down very smooth.

Drinkability: Excellent drinkability. You could knock back a few of these without any trouble.

Overall: Excellent beer overall. This is the best flavor I¬íve ever gotten from a coffee infused beer. I really like that Cigar City went a different direction and blended the coffee with a brown ale instead of a stout. I would highly recommend this beer to anyone, especially coffee lovers.

I am rating Cigar City Cubano-style Espresso Brown Ale, which I take to be the same beer.  Vanilla, semi-sweet chocolate and coffee combine in a rich aroma.  Still has a bad label, plastic and clip art.  Beer is a very deep ruby brown with a slight tan head.  Clean roast, coffee is prominent but not edgy or overpowering.  Moderate bitterness, mostly represented in the coffee and cocoa bean roast.  Not sweet at all.  Medium to slightly light bodied, not fizzy.  Roast finish, with a slight reminder of parched peanuts.  I¬ím not much of a coffee dude, but this was another really good brew from Florida¬ís best brewery.  New Leaf Market.

Clear deep red pour with a thin off-white head. The scent is coffee and chocolate. Taste is amazing, coffee, dark chocolate and nuts. Very balanced and creamy. Really looking forward to CCB coming to South Carolina!

12oz bottle, omg coffee, its like taking a big sniff of Starbucks,delicious. This is by far the best coffee beer I have ever had. It is pretty much delicious beyond belief. Another Cigar City home run.

Bottle thanks to drowland. Pours dirty brown with tan head. Nose is extremely expressive fresh cuban espresso beans, flaked oatmeal and caramel malts. Taste follows suit. I didn¬ít detect the chicory initially, but after reading the description and retasting it is in there.

Bottle,it poured dark brown with small head,aroma of coffee but not overwhelming,taste was malty with a nice soft coffee taste but not real strong which makes this very good,kinda thin but a very drinkable everyday beer.CHEERS!

Tap & bottle: a translucent brown pour w/ almost no head. Bottle aroma was great but tap espresso aroma gave me a coffee-gasm, oh my. That said the front-end to mid taste is a wonderful yet surprisingly thin coffee/malt, given the nose.

Tap. Heavy toasted and strong coffee notes for the malt, moderate resin for the hops, light earth for the yeast and hint of cola, paper and faint tar in the background. Head is huge, creamy, off-white with good spotty lacing and is mostly lasting. Color is dark brown. Flavor starts moderately sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes lightly bittersweet. Palate is medium, watery with a lively carbonation and a dry finish. This tastes exactly like a cup of morning coffee...served chilled and with effervescence of course.
has got a decent amount of spices and strong coffee flavor, but it lacks any real character, its thin palate and very fizzy that blocks off the flavor of something that could be better.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2010 Draft. Pours a clear reddish tinged brown color with a collared tan head. Nice strong aroma of coffee notes, vanilla, and chocolate with touches of a nutiness that is really nice. The espresso really does take center stage though as it should. Nice roasted espresso coffee notes mixed with bitter chocolate and some bitterness. I also get some vanilla and nut in the flavors at the end. Medium mouthfeel. Pretty easy drinking. Not the best coffee beer I have had but very good.

The aroma definitely has the coffee/espresso quality that you would expect from this one. It also has toasted malt and what seams like brown sugar. The appearance is medium brown with a foamy head that seems appropriate for the style. The taste is like the aroma except the coffee adds some negative acidic taste as well as burnt grounds. The palate is typical for the style. Overall a great smelling beer that does not have the taste to match. Still coffee lovers will probably enjoy this one.

A: Pours a dark chestnut brown with a nice tan head and decent retention.

S: Plenty of dark-roasted espresso beans along with hints of chocolate, slightly-roasted malt, and a bit of toffee.

T: Loads of crisp espresso and coffee flavors with some chocolate and sweet malt.

M: Very nice and creamy with an excellent amount of carbonation.

D: Very tasty and goes down very smoothly. Another masterfully-crafted brew from CCB.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 05-05-2010

Mini growler via trade with smith4498 - Pours a dark brown color with a small light tan head that faded pretty quick.  Very light spotty lacing.  Aroma is coffee and herbal hops.  Flavor is roasted malt, chocolate, and coffee.  The malt and coffee linger in the finish.  Medium body.  A nice beer.  Thanks Jason.
Coffee extreme.  A richly coffee¬íd brown ale similar to their Coco Loco but with insanely more coffee.... like a coffee stout... almost like a cold espresso.

Thanks to Kan for this pour!  Brown orange with a white head. Ashy nose old malts some old coffee. Too much old coffee ashiness. Malty chocolate ashy coffee sweetness. Dry bitter finish.  I think I might be over critical of coffee beers, this one¬ís not great, but not bad. 7/47/3/14

DeLand, Fl - on tap - Abbey. Dark brown pour, extremely thick creamy mocha colored head. Fresh, green aroma - pick up a lot of peppers and black coffee. Flavor is very rich with lots of earthy notes. Pick up the same peppery notes, some chicory coffee, perhaps a bit of licorice. Very flavorful and bold. Thick, chewy mouthfeel.

On tap at Cigar City 
Appearance: Pours dark brown with a small off-white head and some light lacing 
Aroma: Toasted malts, espresso and nutty 
Taste: Espresso, dark malts, cedar and sweet chocolate in the finish 
Very nice brown ale

Draft. Clear brown body. Frothy, big-bubbled, off-white head.  Enticing aroma of espresso, roasted malts, milk chocolate along with grapefruit and floral hops. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet and moderately bitter. Medium body, creamy texture and livecly carbonation. Nice coffee taste backed with chocolate, nuts and vanilla.

Bottle shared with Mikkel. Dark brown almost muddy pour crowned with a tanned head that only slowly fades. At first the aroma reminds me a little of a good old fart.. but after that first impression the caramels are revealing itselves with lots of coffee and bitterness. The taste has likewise lots of coffee with a sweet edge. There are some smoke and some vanilla notes on top of that.. The palate is a bit to light to balance the taste. I guess I miss some body here. The finish is bitter, roasty and a little sweet with vanilla and leaves lot of coffe powder...or yeast behind.
on tap, dark brown coffee color, had no head, with pungent coffee aroma, flavor is iced coffee, spice, earthy, nice beer, nice bitter espresso finish

Draught @ CC.  Nose is roast, espresso, brown sugar, light hops. Toasty, roasty, some light espresso ( I¬íve been drinking a lot of straight espresso lately).  Very solid and tasty brown.  Although not as geekified as some of the others on draught, this was probably my favorite drinker. Best brown I have ever had.

32 oz. growler from smith4498- thanks again, Jason!  Pours a hazy brown color with some reddish tints and a small beige head.  Notes of tobacco leaves, espresso, roasted caramel malts, nuts, coffee grounds, and earth.  Medium-bodied, with a roasty, leafy mouthfeel and fairly low carbonation.  I enjoyed this one a lot, after initially worrying that the espresso would be offputting to a non-coffee drinker like me.

growler shared by phaleslu.  thanks!  macademia nuts, a bit chalky.  dry fresh cold coffee beans.   milk chocolate.  smells like espresso beans with a dash of tobacco.     pretty good.   dry.   nice relatively low abv beer from cigar city.

growler, thanks kan! pours light brown with small off white head. aroma of coffee and vanilla, nothing too exciting in the nose. thin body leads to a soft vanilla, coffee, and hazelnut profile with an ashy finish. really watery and thin, probably my least favorite CCBC beer I¬íve had yet.

Hand-bottle from a fellow man to waste his life and education on the tuba:  Mr. Danny Rowland.  Pour is black with a small off-white head.  I suspect it lost some carbonation in the hand-bottle.  Aroma is great.  Dirty, black, bitter coffee with just  little chocolate.  It¬ís everything I wished I was drinking in the morning.  Taste is more dirt and less coffee.  The coffee is still fantastic, it¬ís just not as good following the brilliant smell.  Feel is a little thin to support the huge smell and taste.  Finish is just as good as the aroma.
Sample from tap at the Treasure Coast Beer Fest 9/11/10 Ft Pierce, FL. Excellent!
